sources.title: Nomads of the North (1920)
sources.description: Nanette Roland lives an unhappy existence in the Northwoods; her father dies leaving her no money, and her fiancee, Raoul Challoner, has gone off trapping for pelts, and has disappeared. She does not want to marry Duncan McDougall's son, Buck, until she is convinced that Raoul is dead. Buck fabricates evidence that Raoul is dead, and Nanette reluctantly agrees to marry him. She is about to be wed when Raoul returns and spirits her away from the ceremony. Raoul and Nanette are married, but Buck goads Raoul into a fight, during which one of Buck's men, Black Marat, is accidentally killed. Raoul is accused of murder and arrested, but Nanette rescues him from jail and they flee into the woods in his canoe. Corporal O'Connor, a dedicated mountie and admirer of Nanette, is ordered after the fugitives. Three years later, Raoul, his wife and baby are living deep in the woods when they are discovered by Buck and O'Connor. O'Connor arrests Raoul, who yields without a struggle, and he and his family begin the trip back when they are trapped by a great forest fire. Buck is caught drunk in a cabin and is destroyed by the fire. Raoul has an opportunity to escape when O'Connor is trapped, but he saves the mountie's life instead. O'Connor sets him free, and says that he will report Raoul as dead. O'Connor leaves the happy family, as they plan to start life anew in the wilderness.

sources.description:
Nomads of the North (1920) is an American silent adventure drama directed by David Hartford and based on the novel by James Oliver Curwood. This restored and colorized edition revives one of the earliest films to feature both human and animal survival against the wild backdrop of the Canadian wilderness. Released during the golden age of silent cinema, the film combines rugged frontier storytelling with heartfelt performances from a remarkable cast, including Lon Chaney, Lewis Stone, and Betty Blythe.

Plot Summary:
Set in the rugged forests of northern Canada, the story follows Raoul Challoner (Lewis Stone), a man falsely accused of murder, who escapes into the wilderness with his beloved Nanette Roland (Betty Blythe). Pursued relentlessly by Sergeant O‚ÄôConnor (Lon Chaney) of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the couple must rely on their endurance, courage, and a loyal dog companion to survive.

As the fugitives navigate harsh terrain, starvation, and violent storms, the drama builds toward moments of suspense and human struggle. Nature itself becomes both adversary and ally, testing the endurance of Raoul and Nanette as they fight to clear Raoul‚Äôs name. O‚ÄôConnor, portrayed with intensity by Lon Chaney, is torn between his duty as a law enforcer and his growing respect for the resilience of the fugitives. The film culminates in dramatic confrontations that reveal themes of justice, survival, and the fragile balance between law and compassion.

Nomads of the North is significant both as a survival story and as an early example of nature-focused filmmaking in Hollywood. James Oliver Curwood‚Äôs wilderness novels were extremely popular in the 1910s and 1920s, inspiring multiple adaptations that blended adventure with environmental themes. The film is also notable for Lon Chaney‚Äôs performance, given just before he achieved greater fame as the ‚ÄúMan of a Thousand Faces.‚Äù

The production was ambitious for its time, with elaborate wilderness sets, dangerous stunt sequences, and the inclusion of trained animals, which added authenticity to the film‚Äôs survivalist narrative. As a public domain work, it offers a rare glimpse into the storytelling styles of early cinema, where melodrama and moral conflicts were woven into tales of survival and redemption.

metadata.Plot: In the mountains, the beautiful Nanette waits for her lost love Raoul to return to her. When the villainous Buck McDougall persuades her that Raoul is dead, she consents to marry him, that is until Raoul suddenly turns up at the ceremony right before vows are exchanged. She returns to the man she loves, which angers Buck. He proceeds to frame Raoul for murder. When Raoul and Nanette run away into the wilderness, Buck gets Corporal O'Connor on their trail, since he also harbors unrequited feelings for Nanette and believes she has been kidnapped.
